titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Education and Public Policy Program (EPP), Office of the Arts, Program Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Education and Public Policy Program (EPP), Office of the Arts, Program Files FA640

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-04 02:59:20 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Education and Public Policy Program (EPP), Office of the Arts, Program Files
did.physdesc: Includes 3 non-standard size boxes and 3 document boxes.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Level 1 Minimal Processing has been conducted to establish basic intellectual and physical control of the material and assess immediate preservation and conservation needs. Material remains as received, in original folders and storage boxes.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 16 series primarily by file type.
Series V. Edward F. D'Arms Interview Notes, 1958-1969
Series VI. Performing Arts Survey Files, 1956-1978
Series IX. Printed Materials and Reports, 1956-1980
Series XII. American Symphony Orchestra Questionnaires, 1961-1972
Series XV. Reference Materials, Statistical Data, Tabulations and Worksheets, 1954

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes but not limited to: program files, grant and grantee files, survey files, comptroller and consultant reports, Edward D'Arms interview notes, reference materials and statistical data.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Foundation-Administered Project (FAP), 06200406 (PA62-406): PROGRAM FOR ADMINISTRATIVE INTERNS (Reel 2561 through 2568).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Edward F. D'Arms's handwritten notes from interviews of prominent figures in dance, music, theater and the visual arts. Also includes correspondence with interviewees, and printed ephemera collected from arts organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a proposal from photographer Ralph Steiner (1899-1986) for a "new kind of center for creative photography in New York City".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1963 Grantees include: Robert Brustein (book on improvisational theater); Maxine C. Gray (project to strengthen regional arts criticism); T.E. Kalem (attend theaters in England and Europe); Stanley Kauffman (visit film directors, producers, writers, and actors in Europe); Jules Langsner (travel project for a critic of art and architecture); Esther McCoy (survey of architects under the age of thirty-five in the United States); Eric Salzman (visit major new music centers in Europe); Franz Schulze, (travel and writing); Jerry Tallmer, (visit European theaters); Wolfe Von Eckardt (critical report on current urban design in major American cities, and comparisons to contemporary urban projects in Europe); and Peter B. Yates (travel the U.S. to discover and meet with creative meet creative artists).

1964 Grantees include: Jean R. Allan (travel and study of American art); Renee R. Hall (visit professional and educational dance centers in the U.S.); Ann H. Holmes (observe resident and repertory theaters in the U.S.); Edward T. Kelly (study of contemporary art in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe); Robert C. Marsh (study of contemporary American opera); Richard O. Martin (study of ballet); Mary Fuller McChesney (audio tape interviews with artists, and book); Julius Novick (study of theater); Gordon M. Rogoff (study of resident theater companies); Jean M. White (development of a program for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts); and Clair Wolfe (study Dada concept and contemporary developments in Pop Art and New Realism).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1963 Grantees include: Robert Brustein (book on improvisational theater); Maxine C. Gray (project to strengthen regional arts criticism); T.E. Kalem (attend theaters in England and Europe); Stanley Kauffman (visit film directors, producers, writers, and actors in Europe); Jules Langsner (travel project for a critic of art and architecture); Esther McCoy (survey of architects under the age of thirty-five in the United States); Eric Salzman (visit major new music centers in Europe); Franz Schulze, (travel and writing); Jerry Tallmer, (visit European theaters); Wolfe Von Eckardt (critical report on current urban design in major American cities, and comparisons to contemporary urban projects in Europe); and Peter B. Yates (travel the U.S. to discover and meet with creative meet creative artists).

1964 Grantees include: Jean R. Allan (travel and study of American art); Renee R. Hall (visit professional and educational dance centers in the U.S.); Ann H. Holmes (observe resident and repertory theaters in the U.S.); Edward T. Kelly (study of contemporary art in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe); Robert C. Marsh (study of contemporary American opera); Richard O. Martin (study of ballet); Mary Fuller McChesney (audio tape interviews with artists, and book); Julius Novick (study of theater); Gordon M. Rogoff (study of resident theater companies); Jean M. White (development of a program for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts); and Clair Wolfe (study Dada concept and contemporary developments in Pop Art and New Realism).
